title: Management of Business Organizations
description: This course uses case studies, project management, team/group dynamics, and strategies to explore the essential parameters that comprise the management of business organizations: planning, organization, leadership, control, and ethics. The course considers the importance of diversity/globalization, human resource management, a comparison of traditional and entrepreneurial leadership, and management as well as business ethics.
requirementsDescription: Prereq: AFM 131/ARBUS 101; Honours Science and Business and Biotechnology/Chartered Professional Accountancy students only

title: Organizational Behaviour in Scientific and Technical Workplaces
description: This workshop uses case studies, lectures, and discussions to explore a basic understanding of how organizations work, and how people interact within organizations in order to achieve ethical human, organizational, and social objectives. This course considers organizational structure and models, ethics, organizational theory, organizational culture, motivation, diversity, negotiation, communication, leadership, and management, and how these principles are applied in start ups or scientific and technical environments. There is a major project that focuses on an aspect of organizational behaviour in a scientific or technical firm or application, and is presented in writing and orally.
requirementsDescription: Prereq: Honours Science and Business and Biotechnology/Chartered Accountancy students only
